clean_story:
"Cities as ecosystems. Wildlife adapting to concrete jungles. "

"Urban wildlife resilience" describes how animals survive—and even thrive—in human-built environments.

Cities seem hostile: noise, pollution, glass towers.
Yet peregrine falcons nest on skyscrapers, using ledges like cliffs.
Coyotes in Chicago hunt rats instead of deer, shifting diets without hesitation.
Their secret? Behavioral flexibility.
Raccoons solve complex locks for food.
Foxes in London time their movements to avoid traffic, using gaps between cars like forest paths.
Some species even evolve faster: urban pigeons develop detox genes to handle pollution.
Green roofs and wildlife corridors act like bridges, reconnecting fragmented habitats.
But resilience has limits.
Light pollution disrupts bird migrations.
Paved surfaces flood burrows.
The balance is fragile—yet adaptable.
Urban rewilding.
Microhabitats in drainage systems.
The unseen rules of animal cities.
